item.description:
I just realized this upcomming weekend is Seek the Peak on Mt. Washington. Since it will be very crowded on Big George, I have set up this alternative hike for those who wish to be away from the crowds.

We will meet at the Lonesome Lake parking lot and then shuttling over to the Mt. Kinsman Trailhead. This will allow us to do a one way thru hike.

Please read the below for additional information.

All attendees must read, understand and agree to the hikers responsibility code and waiver which can be found on this website.

All attendees must at a minimum be able to average 2 miles an hour and to hike two hour stretches without breaks. Know your abilities.

Total distance is 9.98 miles and estimated time is 7:49.

Distance Time Elev
Change
Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude
starting at Mount Kinsman Trailhead 44° 10' 09" 71° 45' 50"
This trail climbs to the Kinsman Ridge Trail, 0.4 mi. north of North
Kinsman from the east side of NH 116 at the Franconia-Easton
town line, about 4.4 mi. south of NH 18 in Franconia village and
2.0 mi. north of the Easton town hall. There is limited roadside
parking; do not block driveways. There is a sign for the town line a
few yards north of the trail, but most of the time, there has not
been a sign for the trail itself, which follows a logging road closed
by a chain gate between two granite pillars opposite a house.
2.10 mi 1 hr 46 min +1391 ft on Mt Kinsman Trail
2.10 mi 1 hr 46 min +1391 ft This trail climbs to the Kinsman Ridge Trail north of North
Kinsman. There is limited roadside parking; do not block
driveways. There is a sign for the town line a few yards north of
the trail, but most of the time, there has not been a sign for the
trail itself, which follows a logging road closed by a chain gate
between two granite pillars opposite a house. The trail climbs at
moderate grades, is well trodden, and has been recently blazed in
blue, but some care is required to follow it, particularly in the lower
section where there are many intersecting woods roads.
From the gate, the trail follows a sandy logging road that ascends
moderately under tall pines, swinging to the right, always taking
the right at forks where several other roads diverge to the left. It
bears right again at the edge of a grass-grown log yard.
Ascending easily, at times level, it swings left, passes an old
sugarhouse that stands on the left, and swings right again. It
makes a short bypass to the left of a wet section of road, enters
the WMNF and turns right off the road (cairn and arrow), then in
30 yd., turns left onto another road. This road, distinctly older and
steeper, crosses a substantial brook near the site of the former
Kinsman Cabin.
to the junction of Bald Peak spur 44° 08' 56" 71° 44' 54"
1.60 mi 1 hr 31 min +1441 ft on Mt Kinsman Trail
3.70 mi 3 hr 17 min +2831 ft Then the trail crosses a small brook that falls over a mossy ledge
to the left of the trail, then crosses Flume Brook. Just over Flume
Brook, a side path on the right descends close to the brook bank
for 150 yd. to small, steep-walled Kinsman Flume, a classic
eroded dike with an overhanging boulder at the top that presents
a reasonable facsimile of a profile. The main trail continues on the
road for another 70 yd., then turns sharp left at the point where
another spur path diverges sharp right, descends briefly, then
makes an easy ascent to Bald Peak, a bare ledgy dome with fine
views that crowns a western spur of Kinsman Mountain.
The ax-blazed trail now joins and follows Flume Brook, winding up
the mountainside at easy to moderate grades, with good footing
except for short, scattered steep pitches with rough footing. It
crosses several small brooks and it swings right and angles
upward, then swings left and climbs straight up to the ridge top,
where it meets the Kinsman Ridge Trail. For North and South
Kinsman, turn right; for Kinsman Pond and Kinsman Junction, turn
left.
to the junction of Kinsman Ridge Trail 44° 08' 15" 71° 44' 05"
0.40 mi 12 min +420 ft on Kinsman Ridge Trail
4.10 mi 3 hr 29 min +3251 ft This trail follows the crest of the main ridge from the height-of-land
on NH 112 in Kinsman Notch to the Cannon Mountain Tramway
parking lot just off the Franconia Notch Parkway (look for the trail
sign on a post in the lot and park nearby). From NH 112 to
Kinsman Junction, it is part of the AT. For much of its length, it is
a more difficult route than one might infer from the map—footing
is often rough and there are many minor ups and downs. Hikers
with heavy packs should allow considerable extra time for many
parts of the trail. There is little water on or near several long
sections of the trail, and none that a cautious hiker will drink
without treatment.
From Kinsman Junction, the Kinsman Ridge Trail (now part of the
AT for the rest of its length) turns right and climbs up ledges to the
junction where the Mt. Kinsman Trail enters on the right, then
continues to climb steeply to the summit of North Kinsman.
to North Kinsman 44° 08' 00" 71° 44' 12"
0.90 mi 35 min +54 ft on Kinsman Ridge Trail
2
Distance Time Elev
Change
Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude
5.00 mi 4 hr 4 min +3306 ft Here a side path (sign) leads to the left 25 yd. to a fine outlook to
the Franconias and continues, descending steeply, another 70 yd.
to a ledge that looks directly down on Kinsman Pond. The true
summit of North Kinsman is a pointed boulder on the left (east)
side of the main trail, 30 yd. north of the outlook spur. The main
trail descends steadily to the col between North and South
Kinsman, then ascends relatively easily and passes 15 yd. to the
west of the north knob of South Kinsman’s summit. The Kinsman
Ridge Trail then crosses a scrub-filled sag to the bare south knob
of South Kinsman, which is very exposed to the weather. (Note:
The section of the trail between South Kinsman and Harrington
Pond may require much extra time, particularly for those with
heavy packs, and is also somewhat exposed to weather.)
to South Kinsman 44° 07' 23" 71° 44' 12"
0.90 mi 35 min -54 ft on Kinsman Ridge Trail
5.90 mi 4 hr 39 min +3251 ft From here the Kinsman Ridge Trail crosses a scrub-filled sag,
passes 15 yd. to the west of the north knob of South Kinsman,
and descends relatively easily to the col between South and North
Kinsman. The trail then climbs steadily to a side path (sign) that
leads to the right; this side path runs 25 yd. to a fine outlook to the
Franconias and continues, descending steeply, another 70 yd. to
a ledge that looks directly down on Kinsman Pond. The true
summit of North Kinsman is a pointed boulder on the right (east)
side of the main trail, 30 yd. north of the outlook spur.
to North Kinsman 44° 08' 00" 71° 44' 12"
0.40 mi 12 min -420 ft on Kinsman Ridge Trail
6.30 mi 4 hr 51 min +2831 ft The Kinsman Ridge Trail now descends steeply to the junction
with the Mt. Kinsman Trail on the left.
to the junction of Mt Kinsman Trail 44° 08' 15" 71° 44' 05"
0.20 mi 6 min -112 ft on Kinsman Ridge Trail
6.50 mi 4 hr 57 min +2719 ft The trail then continues to Kinsman Junction. Here the Fishin’
Jimmy Trail continues the AT to Lonesome Lake, and the
Kinsman Pond Trail bears right, leading to Kinsman Pond and
Kinsman Pond Shelter.
to Kinsman Junction 44° 08' 17" 71° 43' 59"
1.91 mi 1 hr 32 min -997 ft on Fishin' Jimmy Trail
8.41 mi 6 hr 29 min +1722 ft This trail, a link in the AT, leads from Lonesome Lake to the
Kinsman Ridge Trail at Kinsman Junction, near Kinsman Pond.
Parts of it are steep and rough, with wooden steps on ledges. It
received its peculiar name from a well-known local character
called Fishin’ Jimmy—his real name was James Whitcher—who
lived in the Franconia area and was featured in a story by Annie
Trumbull Slosson, once a popular New England author.
From the Kinsman Ridge Trail, the Fishin’ Jimmy Trail descends
gradually from the ridge to the Kinsman Pond Trail. The Kinsman
Pond Shelter can be reached by traveling south a short distance
on this trail. From this junction, the trail begins a long descent. It
curls around a large boulder on the right, passing through a fairly
flat area and then continues to descend, at times steeply but with
occasional minor ascents as well. It then flattens out, crossing
several small brooks then runs around the lower end of a ridge
coming down from the Middle Cannon Ball, making several
ascents and descents and passing over a ledgy ridge crest.
to AMC Lonesome Lake Hut 44° 08' 18" 71° 42' 12"
0.04 mi 2 min -11 ft on Fishin' Jimmy Trail
8.45 mi 6 hr 31 min +1711 ft Then the trail reaches Lonesome Lake Hut then passes the
junction with the Around-Lonesome-Lake Trail near the beach at
the southwest corner of the lake.
to the junction of Around-Lonesome-Lake Trail 44° 08' 18" 71° 42' 10"
0.05 mi 2 min -4 ft on Fishin' Jimmy Trail
8.50 mi 6 hr 33 min +1707 ft It crosses the outlet brook on a bridge then ends at the Cascade
Brook Trail at the south end of Lonesome Lake.
to the junction of Around-Lonesome-Lake Trail, Cascade Brook
Trail
44° 08' 17" 71° 42' 07"
0.25 mi 8 min +22 ft on Cascade Brook Trail
3
Distance Time Elev
Change
Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude
8.75 mi 6 hr 41 min +1729 ft This relatively easy trail, a link in the AT, leads to Lonesome Lake
from the bike path at the former Whitehouse Bridge site, just
south of the bike path’s bridge over the Pemigewasset (the Liberty
Spring Trail begins just north of the bridge). There is no parking at
the Whitehouse Bridge site.
From this junction, Lonesome Lake Hut is 150 yd. to the left. The
trail continues along the east side of the lake towards a junction
with the Lonesome Lake Trail and the Dodge Cutoff.
to Lonesome Lake 44° 08' 25" 71° 41' 57"
0.90 mi 52 min -834 ft on Lonesome Lake Trail
item.how_to_find_us: Dianne and I will be in a black four door Echo with Maine plates. I will also have my yellow baseball cap on.
item.name: NORTH & SOUTH KINSMANS
